question: An electric field is most directly related to:

options.A: the momentum of a test charge
options.B: the kinetic energy of a test charge
options.C: the potential energy of a test charge
options.D: the force acting on a test charge
options.E: the charge carried by a test charge

question: As used in the definition of electric field, a test charge:

options.A: the same in both magnitude and direction as the field found by Bina
options.B: greater in magnitude than the field found by Bina
options.C: less in magnitude than the field found by Bina
options.D: opposite in direction to the field found by Bina
options.E: either greater or less than the field found by Bina, depending on the accelerations of the test charges

options.B: are vectors in the direction of the electric field

question: Two thin spherical shells, one with radius R and the other with radius 2R, surround an isolated charged point particle. The ratio of the number of field lines through the larger sphere to the number through the smaller is:

options.A: at least two point charges are present
options.D: the field points in two directions at the same place

question: Choose the correct statement concerning electric field lines:

options.B: field lines are close together where the field is large
options.C: field lines point away from a negatively charged particle
options.D: a charged point particle released from rest moves along a field line

question: The diagram shows the electric field lines due to two charged parallel metal plates. We conclude that:

options.A: the upper plate is positive and the lower plate is negative
options.B: a proton at X would experience the same force if it were placed at Y
options.C: a proton at X experiences a greater force than if it were placed at Z
options.D: a proton at X experiences less force than if it were placed at Z
options.E: an electron at X could have its weight balanced by the electrical force

question: Let $k=\dfrac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}$. The magnitude of the electric field at a distance $r$ from an isolated point particle with charge $q$ is:

options.A: Y is negative and Z is positive
options.B: the magnitude of the electric field is the same everywhere
options.C: the electric field is strongest midway between Y and Z
options.D: Y is positive and Z is negative
options.E: Y and Z must have the same sign

question: The electric field at a distance of 10 cm from an isolated point particle with a charge of 2×10$^{−9}$ C is:

question: Positive charge Q is uniformly distributed on a semicircular rod. What is the direction of the electric field at point P, the center of the semicircle?

Positive charge +Q is uniformly distributed on the upper half a semicircular rod and negative charge −Q is uniformly distributed on the lower half. What is the direction of the electric field at point P, the center of the semicircle?

Positive charge +Q is uniformly distributed on the upper half a rod and negative charge −Q is uniformly distributed on the lower half. What is the direction of the electric field at point P, on the perpendicular bisector of the rod?
The electric field due to a uniform distribution of charge on a spherical shell is zero:

options.C: only at the center of the shell

question: A charged particle is placed in an electric field that varies with location. No force is exerted on this charge:

options.A: at locations where the electric field is zero
options.B: at locations where the electric field strength is 1/(1.6 × 10$^{−19}$) N/C
options.C: if the particle is moving along a field line
options.D: if the particle is moving perpendicularly to a field line
options.E: if the field is caused by an equal amount of positive and negative charge

question: The magnitude of the force of a 400-N/C electric field on a 0.02-C point charge is:

options.A: 200 N in the positive x direction
options.B: 200 N in the negative x direction
options.C: 3.2 × 10$^{−17}$ N in the positive x direction
options.D: 3.2 × 10$^{−17}$ N in the negative x direction

question: An electron traveling north enters a region where the electric field is uniform and points north. The electron:

options.E: continues with the same speed in the same direction

question: An electron traveling north enters a region where the electric field is uniform and points west. The electron:

options.E: continues with the same speed in the same direction

options.A: the field is parallel to the dipole moment
options.B: the field is not parallel to the dipole moment
options.C: the field is perpendicular to the dipole moment
options.D: the field is not perpendicular to the dipole moment

question: The torque exerted by an electric field on a dipole is:

options.A: parallel to the field and perpendicular to the dipole moment
options.B: parallel to both the field and dipole moment
options.C: perpendicular to both the field and dipole moment
options.D: parallel to the dipole moment and perpendicular to the field
options.E: not related to the directions of the field and dipole moment

question: The diagrams show four possible orientations of an electric dipole in a uniform electric field $\vec{E}$ . Rank them according to the magnitude of the torque exerted on the dipole by the field, least to greatest.

options.A: the field does positive work and the potential energy increases
options.B: the field does positive work and the potential energy decreases
options.C: the field does negative work and the potential energy increases
options.D: the field does negative work and the potential energy decreases

question: The dipole moment of a dipole in a 300-N/C electric field is initially perpendicular to the field, but it rotates so it is in the same direction as the field. If the moment has a magnitude of 2 × 10$^{−9}$ C · m, the work done by the field is:

The purpose of Millikan's oil drop experiment was to determine:

options.C: the ratio of charge to mass for an electron
options.D: the sign of the charge on an electron

question: A charged oil drop with a mass of 2 × 10$^{−4}$ kg is held suspended by a downward electric field of 300 N/C. The charge on the drop is:
